Award.AwardTitle: Fluctuating Family Engagement on Youth Case Outcomes in Social Control Settings

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
SES-1357230
Leslie Paik
CUNY City College

Family involvement is critical for positive adolescent youths' outcomes in social control settings, but our understanding of how families get involved is still unclear, especially in situations where adolescents are also held responsible for their actions. Judges set conditions for juvenile delinquents to fulfill on their own, but also expect parents to help those youths meet those conditions. Health practitioners encourage adolescents to start managing their health-related conditions such as obesity or diabetes by themselves; yet parents are still involved in buying food for the family, filling prescriptions, or taking youths to appointments. These competing messages can lead to confusion among adolescents, parents and staff as to who is expected to do what, ultimately affecting youths' case outcomes.

This project offers a more nuanced and clearer understanding of family involvement in social control settings by conducting a qualitative comparative study of 60 families in court and health care settings. In looking at how families engage in their youths' cases and the impact of that engagement on the youth's case outcomes over time, the project studies family involvement as a fluid concept shaped by parents' and youths' interactions with staff, their perceptions of the institution and their involvement in other institutions. The study includes interviews with 30 families whose youths have delinquency cases in Family Court and another 30 whose youth go to health institutions for medical conditions such as diabetes or obesity; it also will observe 20 families (10 per setting) over 12 months. The project advances research by providing a new perspective on family responsibility for youth outcomes that more clearly demarcates the parameters of that responsibility, versus that of youths and institutional staff. The comparative focus highlights the organizational context to family engagement and the expanding yet ambiguous scope of parental responsibility in contemporary society.

Broader Impacts

Research findings will provide insight for organizations seeking to solicit family involvement in their youths' cases by identifying the mechanisms by which youth and families might engage, disengage or reengage in institutional interventions. They also will illuminate the ways in which racial, gender and class inequalities can be perpetuated through these institutions and people's general mistrust of such institutions is fostered.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project studied family involvement in adolescent cases in two social control settings, courts and hospitals, seeking to understand how it might change over time and how family members' perceptions of the institution shaped their actions. After conducting 134 interviews and 134 home observations with 63 families in New York City, the project found that understanding family involvement in any one institution requires situating it amidst the family's interactions with multiple institutions. The families in my study had between 2 to 11 institutional involvements such as school, child welfare, housing, Medicaid, hospitals, courts, mental health clinics, drug treatment agencies, and public assistance. While others have previously studied the family as a unified unit across institutional contexts, my findings show that families may take different approaches to different institutions, depending on the situation or context. In addition, family members do not always have the same view about the institutions’ presence in their lives. These findings show that it is important to capture the variations and complexities of families’ lived experiences in multiple social control institutions to see how these interconnected, yet not necessarily coordinated, encounters promote social inequality.

The project also calls for a broader understanding of family involvement that considers its temporal and spatial aspects. Regarding the temporal aspects, families' attention to any one institutional case can be affected by their involvement in other institutions at the same time (e.g., balancing doctors' appointments with court appearances or child welfare visits) or as shaped by their previous experiences of any given institution (e.g., parents' involvement in the same institutions when they were children). The spatial aspects also showed how families' interactions with institutions extend beyond the household as parents often had to deal with institutional obligations of family members who lived in other households (e.g., health issues for siblings, parents, or grandchildren) in addition to their own children's cases in court, hospitals or school.

These findings reveal that multi-institutional involvement potentially mitigates or adds to social inequality, as shaped by an interactional process between these institutions and family members. That process is not a predetermined path but more of a maze whose design unfolds over time, as generated by various institutional obligations and each family's unique institutional histories. This process cannot be captured by studies that view family involvement as a variable affecting case outcomes at set points or as shaped by parents’ pre-existing perceptions of an institution. Qualitative methods – particularly long-term ethnographic observational studies – are uniquely able to capture these nuanced accounts of the interactional process by which institutions and families co-create this maze. 

This research also has significant policy implications, providing insight into increasing family engagement to improve youth outcomes, as it clarifies the reasons for and obstacles to family involvement in institutional settings. By situating the families’ views of and responses to one institutional intervention within the context of multiple institutional involvements, practitioners can see the families’ perceived “noncompliance” actions are not simply a result of misunderstanding or disinterest but as potentially due to previous institutional experiences or competing institutional obligations for family members within or outside of the household.

In sum, the project provides a new perspective does not focus on the family as being solely responsible for how their institutional cases proceed, but rather looks at that process as being co-created by the many institutions working with the family at one time or across generations and households. Unpacking this connection between families and multiple institutions is imperative to understanding how social inequality perpetuates or worsens, given the growing emphasis on individual accountability in social control institutions and fraying social safety net in the US.
